SENT.plain: Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMRI) has emerged as a useful tertiary imaging tool in the investigation of patients suspected of many different types of cardiomyopathies
CMRI images are now of a sufficiently robust quality to enable high spatial and temporal resolution image acquisition
This has led to CMRI becoming an effective non-invasive imaging tool for many cardiomyopathies
In this two-part review we outline the typical sequences used to image cardiomyopathy and present the imaging spectrum of cardiomyopathy
Part I focused on the current classification of cardiomyopathy, the basic CMRI sequences used in evaluating cardiomyopathy and the imaging spectrum of common phenotypes
Part II illustrates the imaging spectrum of the more rare phenotypes
